div.p: Norman Assing, “ Chief of the China Boys,” with a praiseworthy disposition to have justice administered among his subjects in conformity with the laws and by the authorities of their adopted country, appeared this morning before his Honor the Recorder, to complain that Asseck, Arque and Assem had committed an assault upon Ching Ching, during which they had damaged not only his celestial body, but also its cerulean vestment ; and to have meted out to them a proper punishment. His Honor was at first somewhat puzzled how to administer the necessary oath to Ching Ching, the complain-

ing witness ; but Norman Assing offered to act as interpreter, and performed the ceremony by means of a somewhat lengthy harangue, accompanied with gestures very similar to their hieroglyphics, which was listened to by the Court, the witness and all parties, in mute admiration. By the aid of the same interpreter, the witness unfolded his tale, (we do not mean his long queue,) at the conclusion of which his Honor sentenced the accused trio to a fine of 5 dollars each, and one day’s residence among the in-side barbarians of Captain Fallon’s lock-up ; also to contribute sufficient funds to replace Ching Ching’s torn garment ; or, in the words of the decision, to robe him “ in statu quo ante bellum."

Norman Assing rejoiced at the equitable decision of the Court, and delivered his belligerent subjects into the hands of Captain Beck, with sundry moral maxims for them to reflect upon during their confinement.

div.head: The New Year
div.p: THE NEW YEAR.

The New Year has dawned promisingly upon us. We have squared accounts with A. D. 1850. We start anew in life, we begin a new page of history, we enter upon a year yet unsullied with blots and calamities. How refreshing is such a break in the monotony of life, how beneficial such a fresh starting point in the world’s race! How congenial to hope, how provocative of good resolutions is a New Year!

In these our days when events unfold themselves with a rapidity and suddeness that would have startled fair steadier slow going forefathers there is something more than ordinary in the anticipative feelings with which we hail a new year. We have seen what a single year has brought forth, we have seen a year, aye a month, aye a day crowded with events big with importance which in days of yore Would have been spread over a life time. With such precedents before us, and with, the rations of the earth in no state of torpor, we hold our breath in anxious suspense. What shall the year 1851 see ? what shall its historian have to record ? The ceaseless progress of science, the increasing rapidity of communication and facility of locomotion all tend towards an acceleration of life in all its phases. The wonderful activity of the human mind, starting, as it does, from the vantage ground of the labours of all preceding mind, bent as it is in so many million instances, upon the study and elucidation of the properties of physical creation and the application of those properties to the alleviation of human evil and the advancement of our race,—compels us to mingle no slight degree of certainty with our anticipations. We know that at the close of -1851, if-We have not to look back with

wonder and surprise upon mighty changes and convulsions in nations, we shall have to look upon mightier manifestations of the principles good and evil that are stalking through the earth, upon splendid discoveries in the sciences, and upon the application of those discoveries for the well-being of man. Let no one accuse us of usurping the Prophet's place in writing thus : It is evident on the one hand that we have not attained the ulti-matum of truth in any of its brandies political, forensic or scientific, the law of finality evidently cannot yet be applied in the regions of mind and matter. It is evident enough on the other hind that the days of mental slumber are at an end, mind is fully awake and will work and will not be hindered ; it is evident too that in a degree hitherto unknown, the labours of mind are directed towards the practical, the useful, the beneficial, and that one. glimpse of truth, one seeming lucky guess, may as often heretofore, open the door to boundless fields of truth. Thus then with a rich mine only

partially, in how small a part ! explored, with millions of miners patiently and intensity working, are we wrong in confidently expecting that, year by year stores of rich gold should he brought forth for enriching the sons of men ? No ! creation so richly endowed, With so many wondrous properties must reveal her long closed secrets, must give up her stores for the use of man. Constituted Lord of the earth at its creation, man is only now awaking to the extent of his
dominion. A Beneficient
creator is leading him on and pointing how he may make the lightning his messenger and all the elements his servants.
Heartily, then do we wish our readers, a happy new year.

div.head: Pekin Reporter SUMMARY and EXTRACTS
div.p: No. 117, Oct. 20th and 21st, 1850.
Decrees and Rescripts.

The first Decree confers promotion and honor upon a number of the civil and military officers of Shantung Promontory, for their success in an expedition against some pirates, more than 500 of whom they have captured and killed.
The second Decree also rewards certain military officers on the Mongolian Frontier for similar zeal in the apprehension of daring robbers.

In the third Decree His Majesty anxious that his people should suffer as little as possible from the effects of the procession about to he made to escort the late Emperor's remains to the family tomb, commands that for every mow of land trodden down by the cavalcade on their way from Pekin into the Kift District, the sum of one mace of silver shall be paid out of the Chihle Treasury, to enable the proprietors to purchase young shoots of wheat wherewith to replant the ground. This they could easily do as the blade was just then (the middle of the 9th month) shooting forth from the buried seed.

The fourth Decree calls upon the ministers who are in charge of the road along which His Majesty would travel on the 18th day of the 9th month to escort his father’s remains, to be vigilant and watchful, and especially careful that the path prepared for the purpose be not injured by the chariots and horses of the officers and attendants who follow the procession.

The next Decree commands the Viceroy of Chihle to publish an Imperial Proclamation setting forth His Majesty's gracious intention to remit the coming year’s taxes on the six Districts of Wahping, Leangheang, Cho, Fangshan, Laeshwuy and as well as those of the present year, as an extraordinary mark of his benevolence and goodness. These are the districts through which the procession of the remains of the late Emperor would pass on their way to the Imperial tombs. They lie in a S.W. direction from the Capital, the furthest, Yih chow, being 220 le distant from Peking. •
The sixth Decree confirms the appointment of Kingtih to the military command of the Lintsing division in Shantung.

The seventh Decree takes up a complaint made by the Board of War against the Magistrate of Tungshan Hern in Keangsoo, for presuming, a-gainst the form of the statute in such cases provided, to forward to Peking by Government special courier, the application of a military graduate desirous of entering himself for the metropolitan examinations; and His Majesty commands the Governor of Keangsoo to ascertain why the Magistrate in question took upon himself thus to put Government to this excessive and unnecessary expenditure.
The last confirms a subordinate appointment in the censorate.
Memorials.

The first Memorial reports to the Emperor a case of forcible transit through one of the Great Wall Barrier Gates on the part of some Mohammedan sheep drivers wearing blue and white turbans, and carrying sticks and swords, in order to avoid payment of the customary duty, and begs His Majesty to direct the Board of Punishments to treat with the utmost rigour so flagrant a case of contempt of authority.

The second Memorial informs His Majesty of the falling in of the roof of- one of the pavilion temples in the Imperial Gardens of Tsinge yuen whereby the right arm of a colossal statue of Budha has been broken off, and a number of the surrounding idols severely injured, and the Memorialist begs that a competent surveyor may be deputed to examine into the extent of the damage done.

The last Memorial is from a censor advising His Majesty to call upon all his provincial representatives to see the “constant granaries" in every district and departmental town, properly filled up with grain. The primary object of these Government granaries is to provide the people with grain at a reduced and equable price at that particular time of the year when-“green has not resolved itself into yellow ” or in the intervals between the crops, and during times of scarcity and distress. Then when grain is again abundant and the price low, it has to be purchased into store, to fill the granary for future exigencies. These depositions are therefore called “ constant stores.”

div.head: To the Editor of the "North China Herald"
div.p: To the Editor of the
“North-China Herald.”
Mr. Editor,—I have got hold of a well written little Chinese Paper on Early Rising a translation of which I herewith
hand you, and commend the sentiments of the Paper to “ all whom it may concern.”

The “ three glories ” referred to in the Proverb arc the Sun, Moon and Stars ; and the “ three hurries" refer to the books to be read, the business to be transacted, and the daily good deeds to be performed.

div.head: Translation
div.p: Translation.

Every day rise early. The poems of the men Tang observe, when at home make it your constant rule to rise early ; cherish deep anxiety for the welfare of the nation, and heartily desire the year to be crowned with abundant harvests.

It is important for those who are heads of families to be aware that if they rise early, then which of the children of the family, younger brothers, or domestics will dare lazily to sleep ? ' Each servant will then’give attention to his own appropriate business ; diligence and economy will predominate, and daily will be the increase
of prosperity and affluence. The calcula-

tions of each day depend upon the time between three and five o'clock in the morning. Very early in the morning too, all the higher energies of the human system are of doubly increased proportions. During these early hours, in the study of books immense advantages are realized ; and during this space of time too, a vast deal may meritoriously be effected. And furthermore, in the family circle all miscellaneous matters should decidedly be arranged early in the day,
The Proverb says,—
Three brilliant glories on the early riser shine While he who rises late three hurries vex his mind.
Yours, &c., SINENSIS.
Shanghae, 1st January, 1851.

div.head: REPORT ON THE MARITIME TRADE OF CHINA, AND THE PROSPECTS OF THE MORE VALUABLE PORTION BEING Transferred TO FOREIGN BOTTOMS.
div.p: With the Polynesian Archipelago, in connection with the Dutch, Spanish, and English colonies, a large trade is known to he carried on by the Chinese, although the amount is variously estimated by different authorities. The exports from China to Singapore alone in 1814, according to official returns, amounted to 2,073, 233 dollars, and the imports into China 3,256,260; exports from China 1834-5 were 766,955, and the imports into China 1,213,695 dollars. And up to the year 1843-4 the trade with that port has been progressively increasing. With Cochin China, Siam, Corea, Japan, and Formosa there is also a large though decreasing trade. The Junk trade from the different Chinese ports along the coast is very great. Many causes seem to be in operation, the tendency's of which is to divert a considerable portion of the Chinese carrying trade to foreign bottoms. These tendencies, both politically and commercially, may soon be productive of results of great importance and are worthy of attention.
The history of this trade and its progress ; at Shanghae may equally serve I believe with slight modification- for every other port in China.

The Junk-trade with Japan, Formosa, Siam, the Malabar coast, and the Polynesian Archipelago generally, has sensibly deteriorated here of late years, chiefly owing to the risk and losses incurred by piracy. From the same cause great portion of the native Straits’ trade at Amoy, has we know fallen into the hands of Europeans, and is carried on under the Spanish flag on Chinese account.
The following-facts collected by a body of our merchants here for their own use, bear out this view:—

" To the end of July in the year 1847, 4 junks only appear to have arrived here from Siam of 8 to 9,000 piculs burden, bringing pepper, sandal wood, mangrove bark, rattans, &c. ; 5 from. Singapore of from 4 to 5,000 piculs, bringing in addition to the same articles, ebony, bicho de mar, and sea-weed. The capture of a large Siam junk, and the detention of a Fokeen junk from Formosa with 5,000 piculs of sugar, the latter held to ransom, was currently reported at the same time. The Yang-tsze-keang for several Weeks was kept in a state of blockade for Chinese vessels, by a fleet of piratical junks.”

“ The trade from Manila which in former years employed several junks, and latterly one annual junk, in 1847 gave employment exclusively to two Spanish vessels, the Veloz and Cebuana, which were chartered and loaded with return cargoes by Chinese, chiefly articles of Chinese use and consumption."
The adverse influences which have
tended so strikingly to curtail and injure

the native maritime trade of China, nearly destroying the Straits’ trade at this port, hold out the promise of a speedy transfer of the more valuable portion of that which remains to foreign bottoms, exempted from the dangers, delays, and losses attending the voyages of the junks. The same causes which have realized the promise at Amoy may be safely counted upon here.

In my report of the native trade of Foochow in the year 1846, I drew attention to the fact that although 1,625 junks had entered, representing some 120,000 tons of shipping, and a trade estimated at 16,000,000 dollars, it was greatly curtailed by the risk from pirates having compelled the merchants to resort to the more costly transit inland of all manufactured goods, and the more portable articles of value. “Piracy,” I observed in despatch of 3rd September, 1846, “seems on the increase, and seriously damages and curtails the whole of the coast trade. The Chinese authorities ap-pear to have little inclination and less power to put an end to this evil ; and if our trade with the Consular ports be in any degree dependent upon their pros-

transactions at each and along the coast the expediency and practicability of af-fording that protection to the native trade which the Chinese cannot themself provide, may be worthy of considera-tion.”

Efforts have since that date been made by Her Majesty’s Government to check the piracy on the coast, and several captures it appears have been made by Her Majesty’s Ship Scout. In winter, when large numbers of fishermen and sea coast people are thrown out of employment there are few boats or men, I am led to believe, not engaged in piracy whenever the opportunity can be found.

The only remedy, therefore, which the nature of the case would seem to admit lies in the substitution of foreign for Chinese bottoms, and the transfer of the more valuable portion of the seaboard native trade into European hands. The greatest gainers by this exchange would unquestionably be the bulk of the Chinese nation, whose maritime trade, carried on in security and with less cost, might safely be expected to take a large development

It is true a portion of the maritime population would more or less gradually be thrown out of employment, the shipping interests might suffer by any sudden transfer of capital, and the apparent prosperity of the native trade would be diminished if estimated by the number of junks employed. But shipment of the more valuable cargoes in foreign bottoms would speedily make piracy in these seas less profitable, and thus by striking at the root of the evil render the voyages of junks, laden with more bulky and less available goods, comparatively safe. Moreover nothing is more certain than the rapid deterioration of the Chinese maritime trade. The anticipated result therefore, be it good or evil, will come under any circumstances, and all the sooner if the alternative offered by foreign freight is rejected. The only difference will be, that without the aid of our shipping the loss comes unattended by any of the substantial advantages to the nation and the shipping interests, which the em-ployment of foreign vessels in their trade must of necessity bring, in compensation for a partial and temporary evil.

The argument is still stronger in a political sense, for if the commercial and military marine together be wholly unequal to grapple with the enemy from which the maritime trade of China has long been suffering,—against European aggression on their coasts, both the one and the other are and ever have been utterly ineffective and powerless. The Chinese Empire therefore may gain much in commercial wealth, but has nothing to lose in point of military strength. Finally, the Chinese revenue would in many respects be greatly benefited by a larger trade and less smuggling.

The only immediate advantage to Europe consists in the profitable employment such a trade would afford for a large amount of tonnage ; but indirectly and more remotely', by making the Whole Chinese Empire conscious of their maritime weakness and dependence upon foreigners, for the safe and profitable conduct of the native trade, the absurd arrogance and conceit of this people continually endangering their relations with the civilized nations of the West, might by such peaceable means he abated, and a better feeling lend to that larger, less restricted, and more beneficial intercourse, to which all things seem inevitably to tend, whether war or commerce be destined to prepare the way.

I have not been able satisfactorily to ascertain the relative cost of transport in Chinese and British vessels, it varies so much according to the port, the season, and the partnership arrangements with the crew, that even a close approximation is next to impossible. Assuming that it may be much less in the junks, the grievous and notorious hazard of loss, by pirates, the delay in collecting fleets large enough to venture on their doubtful ex

pedition, and the longer time occupied by junks in their voyages, must unavoidably make it less onerous to the Chinese shippers to employ foreign vessels, if no difficulty is thrown in the way by their authorities.

The feasibility of carrying out these views is at this moment being tested here, by the shipment on Chinese account of produce in foreign vessels. The Commissioner's récognition of the right of Chinese subjects to avail themselves freight in foreign bottoms, made public by Her Majesty’s Plenipotentiary, September, 1847, has unfortunately not reached the Taoutae through the proper official channel ; and before any final ar-rangements can be entered into in reference to the produce now in port, communication must he had with Keying-

I assume that no question can be raised as to the right of Chinese shippers to pay the duties on their own Produce according to the tariff in force for Chinese subjects. This is not expressly stated in the Imperial Commissioner’s communication
vessels. it is difficult to discover foreign vessels, it is difficult to discover in what the privilege consiste or what concession his Excellency contemplated.
Some difficulties of detail, if not of principle, may naturally be expected to arise before a new trade such as this will
be brought into full operation, but
its importance both to Great Britain and China may well demand patient and per-severing exertion, to ensure a successful

result. Access to the whole coast and Formosa would no doubt be required for the full development of this carrying trade, but even under existing arrangement, the five Ports will furnish a large contingent

Of foreign vessels at present employed on the coast, with the exception of a few Spanish vessels already employed by the Chinese in the Straits’ trade they may be considered as merely auxiliary to the direct European and Indian trade. They are employed to equalise the supply of British goods at the three ports, where they are in demand to convey opium up the coast and bring returns of specie, the proceeds of the latter.

In reference to British trade with the Australian colonies, exports of timber may soon supply a deficiency hitherto felt, and the resent modification in the duty chargeable on unenumerated woods, reducing it from 10 pet cent, to 5 per cent., will facilitate shipments from thence. A similar reduction in the prohibitive duty of 50 per cent, now levied on coarse China ware by our tariff would probably lead at once to an export from Shanghae alone of China ware to the value of some 300, 000 dollars per annum for the consumption of the different islands, whose traders resort to Singapore for supplies from China.

Other products besides timber may also lie found in our Australian settlements to bring in exchange for tea, and another , link thus be added to the commercial chain of wealthy and productive islands stretching across the line from New Zealand to the China Sea. In the midst of these England has already flourishing centres of trade and free ports, to the further prosperity of which China, freed from the incubus of piracy now weighing down the native trade and enhancing the value of all articles of consumption, may be made to her own advantage to contribute.

As to the immediate prospects of a partial transfer of the Chinese carrying trade at Shanghae, a beginning has been made by the successful exertions of Messrs. Turner & Co. This house, under the able management of Mr. Stewart, to whom I am indebted for access to the fullest information upon the subject, has led the way by shipments of sugar from the south, which although probably not immediately or largely profitable to the house, is nevertheless a step in the right direction fraught with advantage if judiciously followed, as will be evident upon consideration of the following facts.

From 300,000 to 500,000 piculs may be received as a safe estimate of the annual importation of that article into the port. This is confirmed by the extent of the operations into which it is found the sugar hongs are now inclined to enter.

The chief places from whence it is im-ported are Formosa, the ports in the Fo-keen Province, and Canton ; the proportion from the latter port must be considerable, although there would seem to lie no doubt that the original cost of the sugar is cheaper at other sources. The first transaction entered into was the importation of 12,000 piculs from that port, and orders on native account could have been immediately afterwards obtained for 50,000 more.

The great bulk of the demand here is for brown sugar of a low quality ; and as the rapid and careful conveyance of this description, which melts and loses weight considerably on long voyages, is a great element in its successful out-turn, its import in European vessels from Hongkong or elsewhere gives it an advantage which, enables it to compete successfully with -the cheaper-bought but junk-borne sugar-

from the other places in these seas. For this, among other reasons, the finer qualities of sugar which scarcely deteriorate imported from Hongkong appear unable at present to compete with the junk sugars from Canton or the other districts, the 5 per cent. import and export duty of our Tariff probably turning the scale against us, but shipped on Chinese account this difficulty may and I trust will disappear.
The collateral advantages to be derived from this new trade, should it prove as successful as it promises, are numerous and important.

1. It will furnish in proportion to its extent another means, besides opium, of laying down funds here, the difficulty attending which is one of the great drawbacks to the trade of this port. The value of the whole annual sugar import here may safely be taken at, 1,750,000 dollars. This will best be seen thus :—
Gross value of imports in 54 vessels of 15,069 tons, in 1846 Drs. 3,888,000
Ditto exports in 50 vessels of 14,159 tons, in 1846... .6,494,000
The surplus value of exports over im-
port. was chiefly paid in opium, with the assistance of only half the present import of sugar. The gross imports at Shanghae might stand thus :—
Value of miscellaneous imports in 54 vessels, 15,
Ditto sugar, say 250,000 picul 15,000 tons 875,000
2. From this estimate it will be seen that in time this single article of the carrying trade may give profitable employment to double the amount of shipping at present engaged in the Shanghae trade.

3. Amoy and its neighbourhood is likely to furnish the cheapest sugar for this market, and could this sugar trade, in its character of simply a carrying trade from one port of China to another, be relieved of the export duty (which falls very heavily upon the lower qualities of sugar, equally 12 per cent.) the influence upon the trade of Amoy would be very important and beneficial ; thus if we take—
The gross imports at Amoy in 1846, in 9,378 tons....................Drs. 775,000
Ditto exports (not fully laden) 38,900
The export of sugar, thence to Shanghae to the extent of only 1/6 of the present Shanghae sugar imports would engage 5,000 tons and equal in value 294,000 dollars. '

It would thus find employment for the British vessels bringing cotton from India and yam from England (the principal Amoy imports), taking them to a port, Shanghae, where they would obtained return cargoes.

4. The trade hitherto carried on in junks between the east coast of China and the Straits having, as has been shown, a tendency to fall into the hands of Europeans, and to employ Foreign shipping, the addition of a large bulky article like sugar, of steady and assured consumption must in all probability greatly hasten this result, it being at present very difficult to lead a vessel entirely with articles of Strait’s produce suitable for one market.

It remains to be seen whether ultimately sugar cannot be imported cheaper from Calcutta, Madras, Penang, and Singapore. But I have entered has fully into the details of the experiment as far as it has extended, because I think it furnishes the best illustration of the important results, direct and indirect, to be anticipated from the transfer of a portion of the carrying trade of the Chinese.

Nor must it be overlooked that this branch of trade is calculated to give very considerable activity to the local trade of Hongkong, and there seems reason to believe that a portion of trade may be profitably diverted to Ningpo by laying down sugar, imported in large quantities annually, and taking in return green teas. It has been ascertained that these can be obtained at Ningpo at 10 per cent. less than sugars would be received in ex-, -change.-

In the beginning Mssrs. Turner & Co.’s operations attracted little attention and possibly were looked upon as losing transactions, but they have answered the end in view ; and if the trade be not overdone this season, its future success seems tolerably certain.

For the fullest development of this, as of every other branch of the coast trade, as sugars are largely consumed here from numerous points of the coast, free access to the whole coast of China as I have already remarked, and especially to Formosa would be advantageous, as also a reduction of the export duty of 2m. 5c. equal to 5 per cent, upon the sugar now imported, and 12 percent, upon the lower qualities. The Chinese transfer their sugar from port to port at a duty of 2 to 3 per cent. The expediency of mooting any question of this nature must however of course depend upon circumstances.
Hitherto the carelessness of the customhouse officers has obviated the necessity for appeal upon—another question the

decision of which may exercise considerable influence upon the carrying trade in foreign bottoms. Vessels employed exclusively in the coasting trade have two or three times been allowed to come in and leave the port without payment of tonnage dues, on production of a port clearance from Canton of some anterior date.

It is contended by some British merchants that they are exempted under these circumstances by the XVth. clause of the French Treaty, where it is laid down that “ lors du paiement du droit précité, le Chef de la Douane délivrera au Capitaine ou Consignataire, un reçu en forme de certificat, constatant que le droit de tonnage a été intégralement acquitté : et sur l’exhibition de ce certificat au Chef de la Douane de tout afutre des Cinq Ports où il lui conviendrait de se rendre, le Capitaine sera dispensé de payer de nouveau pour son bâtiment le droit de tonnage, tout navire Français ne devant en être passible qu’une seule fois à chacun de ses voyages d’un pays étranger en Chine.”— and so long as they are merely transferring goods from one Chinese, port to
another, they are entitled to demand free
clearances for any vessel so long as she does not touch at any foreign port— Hongkong to wit.
In the event of this reading being confirmed, it : will be seen that much of our coast and carrying trade may he exempted from tonnage dues, by avoiding the port of Hongkong.

The facts referred to in this report would seem satisfactorily to bear out the inference that the maritime trade of China, though still large, is decaying in all its more valuable elements, the dread of loss and danger from pirates diverting inland all portable and more costly articles to the great enhancement of price to the consumer and probably diminution of profit to the shipper.

The experience we have had of the eagerness with which the Chinese merchants avail themselves of foreign tonnage at Amoy, and latterly here, may be taken as good evidence of the tendency of these long-existing evils to throw no small portion of the trade into European hands.

The beneficial result to both the Chinese people and ourselves of such partial transfer as has been contemplated does not admit of question, and seems at least as important in a political as a commercial point of view.

It must be in every way important, therefore, to watch the first development of this carrying trade at the different ports, and zealously protect it from any unfair and covert interference on the part of the Chinese authorities, the greatest danger to which it is exposed.
(Signed) Rutherford Alcock

div.head: History of the Conquest of China by the - Manchu Tartars, by M, Vojeu de Binnem, Lyons, 1754. ( Continued from No. 22. )
div.p: Some days after the publication of these regulations, the whole army set forward. It passed the great wall without meeting with the least opposition, and entered into the empire of China the twenty-fifth day of the tenth moon,* that is to say towards the middle of the month of December 1629. The left wing advanced as far as Haneulkoang a tolerably strong post, which the Manchus determined to blockade. But the Governor was not a man who would permit himself to be shut up so easily. He sallied forth from the place with the best part of his garrison, and boldly charged the first Tartars he encountered. The latter stood firm, and the remainder of their troops having arrived in time to succour them, they cut the Chinese detachment to pieces.

The lieutenant of the Governor who had remained within Haneulkoang, had no sooner learned the defeat of his General, than he cut off his hair according to the Manchu fashion, and introduced them within the fort.

The Mandarin who commanded at Tehinkiakeou, acted in a manner still more cowardly. He went out to meet Taytsong who was at the head of the right wing, gave him up the keys of that fort, and yielded himself prisoner with all his men.

It was not thus with the noble Man-, darin who resided at Tsunhoatcheou,§ in quality of Viceroy of one part of Petcheli. As there was no prospect that he would yield himself of his own accord Taytsong was desirous to obtain his submission by writing to him. His letter was urgent and allowed no reply, seeing how powerless they were within the city to make any protracted resistance against the assaults of the Tartars. But the unlucky Viceroy could not make up his mind to so open an act of infidelity, the example of which must be very pernicious at the present conjuncture. He took the resolution therefore to hang himself in despair, and the inhabitants of Tsunhoa immediately opened their gates.
The greater part of the Tartar army
united around this fortress, whence it
made a rapid march towards Pekin. They were already pretty near to it, when Taytsong published the following manifesto, addressed to all the Chinese :—
“ The Emperor of the Manchus, to the Mandarins, soldiers and people of China.”

“It is not long since that we were on the confines of your empire, where we lived, as you well know, a submissive and faithful people. There we formed formerly but one peuple under Yehé, when it pleased one of your Emperors to divide it into two parts and give the best

* The Chinese year contains twelve lunar months, each of twenty-nine and thirty days alternately; but, in order to adjust these lunations with the course of the sun, they occasionally add an intercalary month. The year always begins at the new moon the nearest to the 15th degree of Aquarius; which Is likewise the commencement of the Chinese Spring.
Haneulkoang is situated on the gulf of Leaotong or of Petcheli, in the 38 deg. 20 m. of North Latitude and in the 135 deg. 22 m. of Longitude (East of Paris).
*This post is not to lie confounded with the celebrated passage of Chankiakeou, too distant for Taytsong to have moved against that station.

* Tsunhoa in Petcheli, is a city of thé second order, as the final syllable Tcheou signified, its situation is towards the. 40 deg. of North Latitude, and the 185 deg. 49 m. of Longitude (East of Paris....)

to Yehe it is one of the grievances of which we have frequently complained, without ever having obtained redress. Thereupon we appealed to Heaven, before the beginning of the war; and Heaven has approved it, as you see, in giving us possession of the whole country that extends to the east of the river. ”

“ Taytsou, my august father, content with having achieved this conquest, and breathing forth only peace, wrote to your Court** which did not deign to reply to his letter. War having recommenced, Heaven has continued to favour us up to the present time : whatever is situated to the west of the river, has fallen into our hands. Whatever advantage We have gained, peace has been the object of My wishes. I have neglected nothing to establish peace with you : as my letters testify. Not only has no notice been taken of them ; but We have been contemned, even to indignity, whereupon, after having again addressed Heaven, I again took up arms ; and by the success which has attended them, your Court ought to allow, that it took a very wrong part.”

“ You Mandarins, soldiers and people of China, know that they amongst you who will submit willingly to me, shall receive more honours and riches, than they ever enjoyed under the dynasty of Ming. But likewise all they who shall refuse to submit, shall be put to death without mercy: and do not you lay the blame to me ; it is not I who will condemn them to death, it is your master and his Council.”

“ They reproach me that a Prince of a State so small as mine, never ought to arrogate to himself the title of Ti (Emperor), but I reply that the Leao, the Kin and the Yuen originally possessed but a very small country,that they, nevertheless, bore the title of Ti, and made themselves masters of China wholly or in part. The founder even of the dynasty of the Mings, who was he ? A Hochang Bonze* whom Heaven willed should be raised to the throne: for Heaven raises whomsoever he pleases. Who knows, whether He has not chosen me to become one day your master, and to succeed to the Princes of Ming?"
( To be continued. )
* This people of Yehé can only be a remnant of the ancient Kingdom of Hya destroyed by Genghiskhan. It was situated to the north of the province of Chensi beyond the great wall.
* The river here mentioned is the Lyau, which divides Leaotong into two parrs. Its mouth in at the head of the gulf of Petcheli or of Leaotong.

** This does not agree with what is said at the beginning of this history, if one does not suppose that Taytsou wrote twice to make peace ; for at the time of his first letter, he had not conquered the eastern part of Leaotong.

** The name of Bonze means generally the priests and other ministers of the idolatrous worship both of China and Japan. They mostly live in common. There are also Bonzesses who live in houses apart from the men ; who however keep within their precincts lint indifferently. All the Bonzes are either Lamas or Ho-changs. The Lamas came originally from Tartary, and the Hochangs from India, both profess to worship the idol Fo. The hierarchical order is more sensible a-
mongst the Lamas than among the Hochangs.

div.head: BALI. ( From the Journal of Indian Archipelago, Vol. 4 No. 9. ) ( Continued from No. 18)
div.p: Population,—Bali contains about 1,000, 000 inhabitants, and as they arc remarkable for their industrious habits and the comparative advances they have made in agricultural and manufacturing arts, must be considered as the most important of all the independent nations of the Indian Archipelago. The proportion of people to the square mile is stated by Dutch authorities to be double in amount to that of Java. Although the island is divided into several petty states under different chiefs, a certain degree of combination is created by their all acknowledging the supremacy of the Dewa Agong of Klon-kong, the royal family of which state is said to be lineally descended from an ancient chief whose authority was formerly paramount throughout the island, and indeed extended to the western side of Lombok.
The Balinese are a purely agricultural people, and shew a decided aversion to a
sea-faring life, never venturing abroad on trading voyages, but disposing of the produce of their industry to the numerous

strangers whom it serves to attract. In their physical characteristics they are distinct from all other tribes of the Indian Archipelago with the exception of those of the neighbouring island Lombok, that is to say those of Balinese origin, for the Sasak, or aborigines of Lombok, are evidently identical with the Bugis, Molucca:, islanders, and other Malayu-Polynesian tribes of the Archipelago. The Balinese are fairer in complexion, and of more lofty stature, than either the Bugis or Javanese, and the stiff, wiry nature of their hair, more resembles that of the Mongolians of continental Asia than of any other people. These circumstances, coupled with the fact of the great bulk of the population professing the Hindu religion, has given rise to many speculations as to the origin of their civilization. The same religion is known to have formerly spread over Java, and is supposed to have been introduced from the Indian peninsula, which was probably the case; but Balinese civilization has evidently been derived from a different source, as the accounts of all travellers who have visited tlie island from Java, teem with details of the striking pointe of difference in the characteristics of the two people. From opportunities I have had of comparison, I am inclined to believe that a very close connection formerly existed between the people of Bali and Siam. In their physical characteristics the resemblance is almost perfect, in fact the excellent sketch of a Balinese in Mr. Crawfurd’s History of the Indian Archipelago, even to the mode and arrangement of the dress, would form a perfectly correct representation of one of the lower class in Siam. The style of the houses in Bali, surrounded by walls of brick ;—the form of religion ;—the custom of writing on the leaves of the lontar palm by means of an iron style; —the mode of disposing of deceased princes by burning the bodies on lofty piles ;—the entire system of agriculture, even to the maintaining large herds ol ducks to drive over the cropped paddy fields, and whose eggs are collected and salted to form an article of export ;—the custom of both sexes leaving the body from the waist upwards uncovered, (except on occasions of going abroad, where the females wear a salendong or scar thrown loosely over the shoulders and across the breast), are all identical with those of the Siamese. The court ceremonies, also, very closely correspond The crawling motion by which even a chief approaches his sovereign, first casting loose a long piece of cloth attached to his girdle as a train, is practiced by both people. The Balinese princes are unable to obtain white elephants to grace their studs like the Kings of Siam, but they adopt as substitutes the albino variety of the buffalo, a pair of which is attached to nearly every court.

Whatever may have been their origin, there can be no doubt that they are a highly intelligent and improvable people, and if they succeed in maintaining their independence, will no doubt assume a high position among the petty nations of the Archipelago. As Islamism, although it has made some progress in the sea ports,

has by no means obtained an ascendancy, the Balinese are the more inclined to seek the friendship of Europeans. The slave trade formerly existed in Bali to an enormous extent, but since the Dutch have made the transport of slaves by sea illegal, it has nearly ceased. Great numbers were exported to Java, and even to the Mauritius. At the former place many of the females became the wives of Chinese, who seem to prefer connecting themselves with Balinese than with any other of the island races, (To be continued.)
